source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: Tests of full-size pressure tubes and compact tension specimens having several widths are carried out with emphasis on the size effect on the fracture toughness of the pressure tube material, which is made of heat-treated $\mathsf { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: The hydrogen concentration of the specimens ranges from 10 to $4 0 0 \ \mathsf { p p m }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: and the test temperature from room temperature to $5 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: fracture toughness at maximum pressure $K _ { \mathrm { { C } } }$ decreased rapidly with hydrogen concentration in the region where the concentration was less than $1 0 0 \ \mathsf { p p m }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: In the region where the hydrogen concentration was higher than $1 0 0 ~ \mathsf { p p m }$ , $K _ { \mathrm { { C } } }$ slowly decreased with increased concentration

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: For materials having radial hydrides at a hydrogen concentration of 200 to $3 0 0 \ \mathrm { p p m }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk1
evidence_span: a steep brittle-ductile transition was observed at about $\bar { 5 } 5 0 \ \mathrm { K }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk1

evidence_span: K _ { \\scriptscriptstyle { \\mathrm { C } } } decreased with increasing hydrogen concentration in both materials and was lower for the specimens with reorientated hydrides than for those with unreorientated hydrides

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: For the unreorientated hydride material, in the region where hydrogen concentration is less than 3 0 0 ~ \\mathrm { p p m } , K _ { \\scriptscriptstyle \\mathrm { C } } decreases monotonically with increasing hydrogen concentration

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: in the region where hydrogen concentration is higher than 3 0 0 ~ \\mathrm { p p m } , K _ { \\scriptscriptstyle { C } } maintains a constant value of about 2 0 \\ \\mathrm { M P a } \\sqrt { \\mathrm { m } }

evidence_span: For the reorientated hydride material, in the region where hydrogen concentration is less than 1 0 0 \\mathrm { p p m } , K _ { \\scriptscriptstyle { \\mathrm { C } } } decreases rapidly with the concentration

evidence_span: in the region where hydrogen concentration is higher than 1 0 0 ~ \\mathsf { p p m } 5 K _ { \\scriptscriptstyle { \\mathrm { C } } } decreases slowly with increasing concentration

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk3
evidence_span: The materials are classified into three groups according to their temperature dependency: (1) as-received material. (2) unreorientated 200 to 3 0 0 ~ \\mathsf { p p m } material, and (3) reorientated 200 to 3 0 0 ~ \\mathsf { p p m } material and material with more than 3 0 0 \\ \\mathsf { p p m }
specimen_state: as-received, unreorientated 200-300 ppm, reorientated 200-300 ppm, >300 ppm

evidence_span: The first and the second material group show a gradual increase until they reach the upper shelf region at the transition temperatures

evidence_span: The third material group shows a steep brittle-ductile transition at about 550 K

evidence_span: Effect of test temperature on fracture toughness obtained from burst test

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: A comparison between the results of the compact tension (CT) test and the slit burst test at RT for unreorientated material is shown in Fig. 5
test_type: compact tension test, slit burst test

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: For materials with more than 100 ppm, the K_C obtained from the CT test using specimens 24 and 40 mm in width agreed with the K_C obtained from the burst tests

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: For materials less than 100 ppm, the value of K_C is lower than that obtained from the burst test and decreased with specimen width

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: The compact tension test results for several widths of the as-received material and hydrided material at room temperature are listed in Table 5

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: In the latter material, the hydrides were orientated completely to radial-axial direction by the cooling from 723 K to RT under a constant tensile stress of 150 MPa
process_step: cooling from 723 K to RT under constant tensile stress

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: Three pairs of typical load-crack opening displacement curves and a-c output curves of the as-received material are shown in Fig. 6. where W = 12, 40, and 100 mm

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: Although pop-in at the crack initiation is observed in all CT tests, the pop-in appearing on the load-COD curve became more difficult to identify with increasing specimen width
value: more difficult to identify with increasing specimen width

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: The material classified as hydrided and reorientated in Table 5 failed in the brittle mode on the load-COD curve

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: The fracture surfaces of CT specimens of as-received material are shown in Fig. 7 for specimen widths of 12, 40, 50, 100, and 150 mm tested at room temperature

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: Crack growth was stable for all specimens, with the crack front tunneling at the midsection accompanied by considerable out-of-plane plastic deformation at the surface

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: The triangle shape formed by the crack tunneling was more sharply pointed in the wider specimen
value: more sharply pointed in wider specimen

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: The J-R curves for several specimen widths are shown in Fig. 8 for the as-received material tested at room temperature

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: Irrespective of specimen width, all specimens showed metastable crack growth, or pop-in, at a J-integral of 20 to 30 kJ/m², whose values are regarded as J_IC for this material

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: These values agree with the J_IC for cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb material obtained by Simpson and Clark [8] and Davies and Stearns [11]

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: In the region beyond the metastable crack growth, however, the R-curves are dependent on specimen width (i.e., with increasing specimen width they show steeper and higher plateaus)
value: steeper and higher plateaus with increasing specimen width

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: J_IC and J_max are shown in Fig. 9 as a function of CT specimen width, where J_max is the J-integral value evaluated at the maximum load by Eq 4 for tests at room temperature

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk4
evidence_span: For the as-received material, J_max of the CT specimens is observed to increase with increasing specimen width and approach that of the pressure tube above a specimen width of 200 mm

evidence_span: the mean value of the three K_C values obtained from the burst tests at room temperature of the as-received material

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: K_C decreased monotonically with increased hydrogen concentration in the pressure tube burst tests at room temperature using hydrided and unreorientated materials

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: K_C maintained a constant value of about 20 MPa√m when hydrogen concentration was higher than 300 ppm

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: K_C decreased rapidly with hydrogen concentration in the region where the concentration was less than 100 ppm

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: K_C slowly decreased with increased concentration in the region where hydrogen concentration was higher than 100 ppm

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: K_C value seemed to converge to almost the same value of 20 MPa√m for the unreorientated material

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: a steep brittle-ductile transition was observed at about 550 K

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: fracture toughness K_C was independent of hydride concentration in the upper shelf region at 573 K

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: J-R curves showed a strong dependence on specimen width (i.e., they showed steeper and higher plateaus with increased specimen width)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: fracture toughness at the maximum load, K_C or J_max, showed a strong dependence on specimen width

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: Both of these values for compact specimens increased with width and asymptotically approached those for the pressure tubes

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk6
evidence_span: The Failure Assessment Diagram in which the Dugdale model was used gave a good estimation of unstable fracture for the as-received material at room temperature

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk7
evidence_span: Does the measured upper shelf fracture toughness depend on the initial crack length of the burst specimen?

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk7
evidence_span: We think that the fracture toughness at the upper shelf depends on the initial crack length and the fracture stress of the burst specimen.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk7
evidence_span: When the initial crack is short and the fracture stress is higher than that of about 0.5 σ_y (σ_y; yield stress), the fracture toughness will decrease with shortening of the initial crack length.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_009_chunk7
evidence_span: when the initial crack is enough long (i.e., the fracture stress is lower than that of about 0.5 σ_y, the fracture toughness is independent of the initial crack length of the burst specimen.
